user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 8.13 is: A pointer should point to a const-qualified type whenever possible.

</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of send_bad_request:
```c
static enum MHD_Result
send_bad_request (struct MHD_Connection *con)
{
  struct MHD_Response *res;
  enum MHD_Result ret;

  res =
    MHD_create_response_from_buffer_static (strlen (BAD_REQUEST_PAGE),
                                            (const void *) BAD_REQUEST_PAGE);
  ret = MHD_queue_response (con, MHD_HTTP_BAD_REQUEST, res);
  MHD_destroy_response (res);
  return ret;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are close to the target function send_bad_request:
#define BAD_REQUEST_PAGE "<html>\n""<head>\n""<title>WebSocket chat</title>\n""</head>\n""<body>\n""Bad Request\n""</body>\n""</html>\n"
</additional code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
res =
    MHD_create_response_from_buffer_static (strlen (BAD_REQUEST_PAGE),
                                            (const void *) BAD_REQUEST_PAGE);
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 8.13 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: No violation: the call explicitly casts the string literal to a const-qualified pointer ((const void *)BAD_REQUEST_PAGE) and strlen() already takes a const char*. Thus the pointer passed points to a const-qualified type. A violation would occur if the code cast to or passed a non-const pointer (e.g. (void *)BAD_REQUEST_PAGE or if the API required a non-const pointer and the literal were used without const), but that is not the case here.
